description:
Sinocyclocheilus anshuiensis is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the genus Sinocyclocheilus, which is endemic to China. This species is found in the Anshui River basin, a tributary of the Yangtze River, located in the Guizhou province of southwestern China.

Sinocyclocheilus anshuiensis is a member of the family Cyprinidae, which includes a diverse group of carp and minnow species. This fish is characterized by its distinctive morphological features, such as a rounded and robust body shape, a large head, and a terminal mouth. The species is known to exhibit a range of coloration patterns, including shades of brown, yellow, and gray.

One of the notable characteristics of Sinocyclocheilus anshuiensis is its adaptation to the underground cave systems of the Anshui River basin. This species has evolved to thrive in the dark, nutrient-poor environments of these cave habitats, which often lack direct sunlight. As a result, Sinocyclocheilus anshuiensis has developed specialized traits, such as reduced or absent eyes and pigmentation, as well as enhanced sensory organs to navigate its subterranean environment.

The ecology and behavior of Sinocyclocheilus anshuiensis are not well-documented, but it is believed to play a role in the overall biodiversity and ecosystem functioning of the Anshui River basin. The species' conservation status is currently assessed as "Vulnerable" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), primarily due to threats from habitat degradation and loss.
